title: 103_hr3300
content: The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act to promote wildlife conservation on military reservations. Integrated natural resource management plans are required for military installations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with exceptions if the Secretary deems it inappropriate. Conforming amendments are made to Title I to reflect this change. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with exceptions if the Secretary deems it inappropriate. Amendments include replacing "cooperative plan" with "integrated natural resource management plan" in various sections of the Act. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. This includes replacing "cooperative plan" with "integrated natural resource management plan" in various sections of the Act, such as wetland protection and restoration. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. This includes addressing the needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation. The amendment also emphasizes wetland protection and restoration, conservation needs for all biological communities, and the establishment of specific natural resource management goals, objectives, and time-frames for proposed actions. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. The plans must address the needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation, ensure consistency among activities, prevent loss of capability for military missions, allow sustained public use of natural resources, provide necessary public access, and enforce natural resource laws and regulations professionally. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. Plans must address fish and wildlife management, land and forest management, wildlife-oriented recreation, ensure consistency among activities, prevent loss of military mission capability, allow sustained public use of natural resources, provide public access, and enforce natural resource laws professionally. Additionally, the Secretary of Defense must allow public comment on each integrated natural resource management plan. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, including fish and wildlife management, land and forest management, wildlife-oriented recreation, and public access. The Secretary of Defense must allow public comment on each plan. The Secretary of each military department must review all military installations in the United States to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. A report on these determinations must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense, who will then report to Congress within 12 months. The Secretary of Defense must review all military installations in the United States to determine the need for integrated natural resource management plans. A report must be submitted within 12 months, listing installations where such plans are not deemed appropriate, along with explanations. Plans must be prepared and implemented for installations where deemed appropriate within 2 years. The Secretary of Defense must review all military installations in the United States to determine the need for integrated natural resource management plans. Plans must be prepared and implemented for appropriate installations within 2 years, with public comment opportunities provided. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is further amended by adding subsection (g) which requires the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually. The report must include the number of plans in effect, amount of money spent on conservation activities, and details on the Legacy Resource Management Program. The Secretary of Defense must annually review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans, including expenditures under the Legacy Resource Management Program. The Secretary of the Interior must also submit a report on conservation activities and expenditures in consultation with State agencies responsible for fish and wildlife management. The Department of the Interior and State agencies must report on expenditures for conservation activities under integrated natural resource management plans to specified congressional committees. SEC. 6 amends Title I to allow the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws on conservation of natural resources on military installations. SEC. 7 requires each military department to have trained personnel for natural resource management. SEC. 8 provides definitions. SEC. 8 amends Title I by adding definitions after section 107. SEC. 108 defines key terms such as military department, military installation, state fish and wildlife agency, and United States. SEC. 9 adds a short title to Title I as the 'Sikes Act'. SEC. 10 amends cost-sharing basis in cooperative agreements. SEC. 11 repeals a section from a previous Act. SEC. 12 makes clerical amendments. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections, including sections 101, 102, and 103. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends sections related to programs on military installations and public lands by updating the years for authorizations of appropriations to 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997.
